B2_1_explain: Yes, our agency has specific requirements that detail our reporting requirements. General expectations are communicated in provider contracts and we have specific expectations that are communicated in training documents and in a best practice document. These documents detail the data fields, selections, and frequency with which providers must send data.
B3_1_explain: We have two data systems for reporting mental health data. One system contains data from our state-operated facilities (Avatar) and the other system contains information we collect from our private not-for-profit agencies. The data is combined into what we call our Enterprise Data Warehouse. We maintain separate systems for collection of mental health data because we are both an administrator and a provider of services. The state-operated data system is a commercial system and must have the flexibility to be able to bill for services we provide.

D8: ODMH receives General Revenue Funds from the Legislature to: (1) directly operate Regional Psychiatric Hospitals, and: (2) allocate funds to 50 Local Mental Health Boards (covering 88 Counties) to assess local mental health needs and buy mental health services from independent, ODMH certified, Non-profit mental health Providers to meet local assessed need.  Local Mental Health Boards also collaborate with and provide service agreements with non-mental health local and regional services, e.g., local vocational rehavilitation entities.

D8: The Division of Substance Abuse and Mental Health collaborates and coordinates state-wide efforts for supported employment expansion with Voc Rehab through multiple partnerships including training and technical assistance.  We have more than 4 ICCD certified Clubhouses in the State that provide supported employment services as the local MH authority or their sub-contractor.  Additional resources are being established to further integrate supported employment into the service array they provide.
D9: I would like more information on what is happening in other States to address supports for Employment to consumers of mental health services as the funding moves from Voc Rehab to the MH agency.  I would also like to understand how that funding is being shifted and how it is designated to assure that we are receiving the money intended and that we understand what we are accountable to do with the money.  As we pass through most of our money to the Local Mental Health Authorities we need to understand this so we can educate and train them on this important change.

D8: Indiana does not provide services through its state level MH agency other than in the state hospitals.  The MH agency contracts with non-profit organizations throughout the state that actually provide mental health and addiction services.  Most of these organizations have a supported employment program and have contracts with VR but this is not a contractual requirement of the MH agency.  Since your survey is specific to employment and related services, most of the questions are not applicable to this agency.  The data that we collect related to supported employment is limited to whether or not the person is receiving supported employment services and whether or not the individual has employment.  On question D3, we indicated funding supports that are being accessed by one or more of the local organizations.  None of these funds are received by the state MH agency.

D8: although our data systems aren't conjoined, SRS receives data from a variety of different agencies if they request data, or we need data to plan, develop or implement policies. It is important to note that the infastructure of the Kansas MH system impacts the data submitted.  Kansas operates a concurrent 1915 b/c Waiver.  Under this program specific CPT codes reimburse at an enhanced rate for providers that meet fidelity.  The analysis and reporting of the members served (April 2011-June 2011) is approximately 4,000.  However, the data does not allow for a break out of transitional employment supports from other formats. Nor does it account for members accessing supported employment at agency's that do not meet the fidelity criteria, yet provide supports to members to access and maintain competitive employment.   In addition, this number reflects only those members with active medicaid eligibility and does not account for the members (approx 70,000 in Kansas) accessing Mental Health services that are non-Medicaid or uninsured.  A portion of these individuals also may be accessing supported employment services.

D4_8_specify: VR contracts with vendors to provide supported employment.  Contract language states that the contractor will provide Long Term Supports or make sure that it is carried out.
D5_8_specify: Local Managing Entity Contracts. Some LMEs contract with the same SE vendors that VR does.   Those who do contract with the LME have a better chance of having the long term support funded, whereas those who are not part of the LME system have no such opportunity.  Also, some LMEs provide LTVS mainly to those with DD/ID disabilities and MH/SA do not get the equal amount of support/funding.
D8: The numbers and figures were persons served with MH state dollars only. Additionally, we did not answer question A7 because it asked for ""operations budget"". However the total amount of service claims for all MH services in FY2010 were $93,696,067 and the total amount of employment-related service claims were $684,029, or less than 1% of the total service dollars expended.  It is important to note that most of our consumers are referred to VR for employment services and that our MH Agency is more involved in the long-term support part of employment.
D9: We would benefit from ideas on how to increase employment outcomes and how to focus on best practices around employments; how to help providers encourage and fund supported employment for MH consumers; how to ensure that local managing entities make employment a priority in their funding allocations, service array and programmatic structure. Also, how to best educate consumers and family members on on reducing fears of working (i.e., not being ""ready"", losing benefits) and accessing community inclusive services.

D7_1_describe: The Idaho Home Outreach Program for Empowerment (ID-HOPE) program provides 9 month Critical Time Intervention (CTI) services to individuals with behavioral health diagnoses who do not have Medicaid or other supports. The ID-HOPE team is half bachelors/masters staff and half Certified Peer Specialists (also able to model recovery and resilience). The ID-HOPE team has been trained on Supported Employment, SOAR and Supported Housing in addition to the EBP of Critical Time Intervention. During the 9 months that an individual is enrolled in ID-HOPE, the team assists with employment needs and helps to connect those able and wanting to work with employment opportunities and resources that will allow this to be successful.
